message:update.title: Release of Breeze::OS v1.1
message:update.description:
Point release 1.1 of the Breeze::OS GNU/Linux distribution which is based on the Slackware 14.1 release. The Xfce, KDE, and Mate flavors are offered. The Mate flavor is from the Salix repositories.
No ISO(s), for version 1.1, are currently available; because of the booting problem mentioned in the news item number 4. We decided in the meantime to try a Live-DVD and a netinstall release for April 2015.
First download the upgrade script and signature in the same folder. wget http://www.breezeos.com/distfiles/slackware/i486/1.1/brz-upgrade.sh wget http://www.breezeos.com/distfiles/slackware/i486/1.1/brz-upgrade.sh.asc
Then, invoke the script with the option '-slack' if you are upgrading from a Slackware 14.0/14.1 distro; or without option, if you have our distro installed on your computer.

message:update.title: Release of Breeze::OS v1.2
message:update.description: This release is the last and long-term point release for versions 1.x; and it is still based on the Slackware 14.1 release, with the Xfce, KDE, and Mate desktops being offered, It contains packages, i.e. OpenOffice 4.1.2, which were updated for either enhancements, bugs, or security issues. It also contains a new display manager called brzdm derived from Slim. The source code for brzdm will be hosted at https://www.github.com. The Linux kernel 4.1.17 has also been added. The main new features, which have been added to the package manager, are the facility to websync your installation with updated binary packages; as well as, the capability to compile from source using slackbuilds. An additional feature was added to view security advisory from Slackware. Each package, by default, has its checksum and GnuPG signature verified; you, now, must turn off verification, when desired. You can, now, just issue the command brzpkg --websync to download and install updated binary packages; brzpkg -A to view security advisory news; and, brzpkg -B or brzpkg -I -b to install a package from source. Before proceeding, you must first update the packager itself, by invoking 'brzpkg --update brzpkg'; then, invoke 'brzpkg --force --upgrade 1.2' to proceed with the upgrade. If a problem occurs, use the script brz-upgrade.sh.

message:update.title: Release of Breeze::OS v1.3
message:update.description: This release becomes the new long-term point release for versions 1.x [32-bit], with the Xfce, KDE, and Mate desktops being offered. It contains packages, i.e. OpenOffice 4.1.3, which were updated for either enhancements, bugs, or security issues. The Breeze::OS installer brzinst, now includes an encryption page, allowing you to setup disk encryption for your installation. It can also be invoked, as just another session, by using our display manager brzdm. The package manager is now, also offered in a self-run package; allowing it to be run independently of the installed packages. You can download it; and execute it in console mode. It is located at https://tsert.com/breeze/distfiles/slackware/i486/1.3/brzpkg-x32.run Just invoke 'brzpkg-x32.run -- --upgrade 1.3:i486' to proceed with the upgrade. If you have problems downloading; try setting the options use-random-http-agent and use-brzpkg-http-agent to no or false, in the settings file /etc/brzpkg.settings.cfg. Also try to put www.breezeos.com first in the option distfiles.
